AMENDMENT OF STANDING ORDERS

(Motion)

 

5.29 pm

 

     The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lim Swee Say): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

 

     That this Parliament resolves that the amendments set out in Appendix 1 to the Report of the Standing Orders Committee as contained in Paper Parl 2 of 2010 be and are hereby made to the Standing Orders of Parliament.

 

     Sir, at the sitting of Parliament on 16th September this year, a resolution was approved by the House empowering the Standing Orders Committee to consider and report on necessary amendments to the Standing Orders of Parliament. Members were invited to submit their proposals for the Committee's consideration. No proposal was received from the Members by the deadline of 27th September 2010.

 

     As part of the Committee's consultative process, a discussion was held with representatives of the House drawn from the ranks of the Government Parliamentary Committees, Opposition and Nominated Members' bench. This was to seek their views on the key changes proposed to be made to the Standing Orders. 

 

     Under the chairmanship of the Speaker, the Committee deliberated the views and feedback given. It has recommended that the proposed amendments set out in Appendix 1 be made to the present Standing Orders of Parliament.

 

 

     Sir, the Committee has made 29 recommendations. Some of the amendments are new procedures, some are formalisations of existing practices by the House, some are liberalising the current procedures to achieve greater flexibility, and the rest are housekeeping amendments.

 

     There are three key areas of procedure or business which the Report covers. They pertain to:


     (a) speech times;


     (b) Supply  business; and


     (c) extension of sitting times by the Speaker.

 

     The Committee also made recommendations in other areas such as Exempted Business Motions, Ministerial Clarifications, Select Committees, Petitions, and House decorum.  I will now take Members through these amendments.

 

Speech times


     Sir, one of the principal recommendations of the Committee concerns the speech times in this House. This is found in paragraph 10 of the Proposed Amendments. The Committee has proposed a reduction in speech times of both the frontbench and backbench, from the current one hour and half an hour respectively, to that of 40 minutes and 20 minutes. In Committee of the whole Parliament, speech time is proposed to be reduced from 15 minutes to 10 minutes for any one speech. Speech time for movers of original motions in Parliament and Committee is also proposed to be reduced, from currently one hour each to 40 minutes for moving the motion and another 40 minutes for the reply.

 

     The Committee feels that 20 minutes for a backbench Member and 40 minutes for an officeholder to express his or her views to any question in Parliament are adequate. The amendment not only allows for more efficient use of time, it will also instil greater discipline on Members in addressing the House. From experience, not many Members take up more than 20 minutes in delivering their speeches. The average time per speech of backbench Members on Bills and Motions for the past two years was less than 10  minutes; in fact, 7.4 minutes to be exact, whilst the average speech time on the Debate on Budget Statement from 2008 to 2010 was 15.1 minutes. For the frontbench and movers of motions, the average speech times were 12.4 minutes (for Bills and Motions) and 19.4 minutes (for Debate on Budget Statement).

 

     Sir, if a Member wishes to have more time to raise issues of substantial importance, he can move a motion for which he will have 40 minutes to state his position and another 40 minutes to reply. Also, the reduction in speech time in the Committee of the whole House to 10 minutes per speech does not affect the current procedure where a Member can speak more than once in Committee. The revised time limit of 10 minutes is also not applicable during the Committee of Supply which allocates time on a block basis. Later, I will touch on this point again under the Supply business amendments.

 

     Sir, the proposed time limits for speeches in Parliament and Committee compare well with those practised in other Commonwealth Parliaments such as Australia and Canada, which are detailed in the Report. In New Zealand, for example, the time limit for most businesses in Parliament is 10 minutes whilst in the UK, the Speaker sets a time limit of seven to 15 minutes depending on the number of speakers.

 

Supply business
Multiple items of Supply business on one day


     Sir, the next recommendation is to formalise a long-standing practice of the House to take more than one item of Supply business on an allotted day. For example, the Supplementary Estimates and Estimates of Expenditure are usually taken on one day of the Committee of Supply. The Supply and Supplementary Supply Bills have also been conventionally taken on the same day at the conclusion of the Committee of Supply (COS). This recommendation is stated in paragraph 16 of the Proposed Amendments. The proposed change to the Standing Orders will accord more flexibility to the House to deal with Budget debates in a timely manner.

 

      I wish also to assure Members that ample notice of the allotted days for discussion on the Main and Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure, Second Readings of the Supply Bill and Supplementary Supply Bill will be given to Members, as in the existing procedure. The scheduling of more than one Supply business on an allotted day is also practised in other Commonwealth Parliaments, such as Malaysia and Australia.

 

10-minute limit on a COS speech


     The Committee proposes to lift the current 10-minute time limit for a speech made by a backbencher in the Committee of Supply. This is set out in paragraph 20 of the Proposed Amendments. Members are then free to allocate their speech times in COS in whatever manner they choose, subject only to their individual block-time cap and the guillotine times.

 

Question Time on allotted days


     The Committee proposes to allow the Speaker to specify a shorter Question Time on days that are allotted to any business. Generally, these will be days allotted to Supply business, Debate on the Budget Statement and Debate on the President’s Address. The House has, by practice, given its approval for Question Time to be shorter on days when the Budget Statement and Supply business are considered, in view of the priority for the completion of these businesses. This amendment to the Standing Orders is recommended in paragraph 7 of the Proposed Amendments.

 

Extension of sitting times by the Speaker


     Another recommendation of the Committee is that of empowering the Speaker or the Chair in Committee to extend the sitting time by up to 30 minutes at the end of the day. This recommendation is found in paragraph 1 of the Proposed Amendments. The short time extension, which is also exercisable by the Chairman in the Committee of Supply, is to facilitate the completion of speeches or matters that are about to end at the adjournment time, instead of being cut-off at that moment. Should the business require more than 30 minutes beyond adjournment time or the moment of interruption, an Exempted Business motion can be moved to obtain the House’s approval for a longer sitting.

 

Other procedural areas


     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I will now touch on recommendations pertaining to other procedural areas.

 

Exempted Business motion


     Paragraph 3 of the Proposed Amendments sets out the proposal to widen the time window for which an Exempted Business motion can be moved to enable the House to sit beyond the moment of interruption. With the proposed amendment, such a motion can be moved any time after Question Time, instead of the current period of 6.00 pm to 6.30 pm. In this way, Members will benefit from the earlier notification of an extended sitting.

 

Ministerial clarifications


     The Committee recommends to liberalise the procedures for Ministerial clarifications. Currently, Ministerial clarifications are taken at the appointed time for Ministerial Statements or Personal Explanations and not thereafter. In paragraph 8 of the Proposed Amendments, it is proposed that, with the leave of the Speaker, brief Ministerial statements and clarifications on concluded proceedings can be made at any time between subsequent items of business. This will facilitate corrections or clarifications to be made to the House at the earliest opportunity at any part of the sitting as long as they are not taken in the midst of an ongoing debate.

 

Select Committees


     The Committee proposes to formalise the current practices and procedures followed by Select Committees. Paragraphs 22 to 26 of the Proposed Amendments deal with the powers of the Select Committee to exclude non-Committee Members and strangers from its meetings, and to exclude from its Report minutes of evidence taken in private; the non-disclosure of minutes of evidence which are not included in the Committee’s report to persons other than Committee Members; and the election of a temporary Committee Chairman in the absence of the Chairman where the Chairman is not the Speaker. Other Commonwealth Parliaments such as Australia and India also have these provisions in place.

 

     Sir, there are other minor amendments included in the Report of the Committee. The slight changes to Petitions procedures are set out in paragraphs 4 to 6 of the Proposed Amendments; and the restatement of Standing Order 52(d) in paragraph 11 to reflect the desired decorum and behaviour to be observed by Members at all times. The amendment in Standing Order 52 seeks to emphasise the necessity for Members to give their full attention to the proceedings in Parliament at all times and the avoidance of behaviour that distracts others from these proceedings. This is to ensure that proceedings of the House are always conducted with order and decorum.

 

     Finally, there are housekeeping amendments stated in paragraphs 27 to 29 of the Proposed Amendments.

 

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, these amendments to the Standing Orders, as recommended by the Committee, have been made as a result of much deliberation and consideration. Their purpose is to put in place the necessary rules that will enable the House to keep pace with changing circumstances, improve use of time and meet the procedural needs of Members in discharging their duties in this House. Sir, I urge Members to support these recommendations and adopt the Report of the Standing Orders Committee.

 

     Sir, I beg to move.

5.43 pm

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Standing Orders have undergone several changes over the years and these changes have helped refine the parliamentary procedures.

 

     Sir, I believe backbenchers, like myself, are thankful for the refinements over the years as they strengthen the process and improve the participation of Members of Parliament (MPs) and engagement of Ministers.

 

     I applaud the proposal pertaining to conduct of MPs in the Chamber.  Sir, it is important that we demonstrate in this august Chamber exemplary behaviour, our respect and consideration for our fellow Members when they are speaking and for Parliamentary proceedings.

     Sir, in support of this amendment, I am glad that I have delivered my speech within the 10 minutes. In any case, though the current time limit is 30 minutes, I have seldom gone beyond 15 minutes. So, I believe the 20-minute limit will not have any negative impact on Members.

 

     On this note, Sir, I support the amendment.

     Sir, Mdm Ho made a few points. First, she observed that the revised time limits are still generous as compared to the other Commonwealth countries. I think this point is worth emphasising. Over the last three years, backbencher-Members of this House made a total of about 119 speeches on Budget Statements. JUVENILE DELINQUENCY
(Effectiveness of programmes)

     1.   Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) if he will provide an update on the state of juvenile delinquency in Singapore and the effectiveness of the prevention and reformative training programmes; and (b) whether more support should be given to youth centres in HDB neighbourhoods to reach out to youths-at-risk.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:

     As a society, we strive to build a safe and secure environment for our young to grow up in. We invest heavily in the healthcare and education of our youth and children. While the majority of our youths mature to be contributing citizens of society, a small number of them go down the path of delinquency and crime.

 

     Over the years, the number of arrests of juveniles aged seven to 15 has dropped from 2,637 in 2004 to 1,783 in 2009. Shop theft is the most common offence committed. Arrests for rioting are also of concern, accounting for one in 10 juveniles arrested.

 

     The decrease in juvenile arrests indicates that our efforts have helped our young stay away from crime. Crime prevention roadshows and prison visits for students educate our youths on the consequences of breaking the law. Parents are also alerted of their children’s at-risk activities through the "Youth Hanging Out Late" letters by the Police. Under the Enhanced STEP-UP Programme, local community agencies provide client-centric intervention to guide students at risk of dropping out of school to be re-engaged either with schools or alternative meaningful activities.

 

     For the youth offenders, we have a range of community- and institutional-based rehabilitative programmes to help them learn from their mistakes and get a second chance in life. The Guidance Programme and Probation Programmes provide youths who committed petty offences with offence specific intervention, community service and experiential activities to teach them positive life skills and reduce the risks of re-offending. Offenders placed in the institutional Juvenile Homes spend about two to three years in a purpose-built facility and attend therapeutic, educational and character development programmes to address the offending behaviour and prepare them for reintegration into society. The StreetWise Programme specifically targets youths who found their way into gangs, and provides them with a series of counselling, life skills, recreational and social programmes as well as academic and career guidance in order to steer them away from all forms of association with their gang and help them make a fresh start in life.

 

     Our rehabilitative efforts are showing gradual positive outcomes. The recidivism rate for the juvenile offenders who have gone through the Guidance Programme, probation or Juvenile Homes has dropped from 23.9% among cases closed in 2003 to 19.8% among cases closed in 2006. Recidivism here refers to having re-offended within three years after completion of a rehabilitation programme.

 

     For the StreetWise Programme, up till December 2009, 1,017 youths have been referred to the programme. Among youths who have completed the programme, only one in 10 had offended within one year following completion. In November 2010, a revised model for the programme has been introduced, which will have greater emphasis on individual and family counselling as well as gang intervention topics.

 

     Despite the low recidivism, the Government recognises that we need to go upstream, to keep our youths away from crime from the start and break the cycle of offending and re-offending early. To strengthen the upstream efforts, the Central Youth Guidance Office (CYGO) was formed in July this year which will comprise officers from the three key ministries – MOE, MCYS and MHA. CYGO has been studying solutions that will enhance outreach to youths-at-risk and coordinate intervention services at the local level to help these youths effectively, and will be piloting some of these ideas soon.

 

     Each and every one of our youths is precious and carries our hope for a better future for Singapore. CYGO and MCYS will continue to work with relevant agencies and explore better solutions that will help our young live a crime-free life so as to develop their full potential to be contributing members of society.
